items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Education Code Section 76140 requires each district to establish its non-resident tuition for the subsequent fiscal year by February 1.  The non-resident tuition fee is composed of two parts:  the tuition fee and an assessment for capital outlay. 
	 
For 2015/16, the base rate was set at the district rate of $135.  The capital outlay rate was set at $17, for a total of $152 per quarter unit (applicable to all non-resident students).
	 
For 2016/17, the statewide rate is $141 per quarter unit compared to the district rate of $141 as per the calculations on page 1 of the attached worksheet.  Under these circumstances, the district has the following options:
	 
1.  Set the rate at the statewide average rate of $141 (plus capital)
	 
2.  Set the rate at the district average rate of $141 (plus capital)
	 
3.  Option 3, as specified under Education Code Section 76140, cannot be exercised as FHDA enrollment in non-credit courses is below 10%
	 
4.  Set the rate to equal the rate of a contiguous district (plus capital)
	 
5.  No more than district average cost, no less than the state average cost (plus capital)
	 
6.  Set the rate at ‘highest years statewide average tuition.’  This rate is calculated to be $141 per quarter unit (plus capital)
	 
7.  Set the rate at no greater than the 2014/15 average non-resident tuition fee of public community colleges in a minimum of 12 states comparable to California in cost of living.  This average is calculated to be $253 per quarter unit (plus capital)
	 
Upon analysis of these options, and in discussion with the Dean of International Student Programs, it is recommended that the base rate be set at $141 (Option 2) for 2016/17, or $6 more than in 2015/16.
	 
The 2016/17 non-resident student capital outlay fee should not exceed the lesser of $22 per quarter unit (see calculation on page 2 of the attached worksheet) or 50% of the adopted 2015/16 non-resident tuition fee of $135, or $67.50.  We are recommending that the capital outlay fee for 2016/17 be set at $15, $2 less than for 2015/16.  Note: Since fiscal year 2010/11, AB 947 amended EC 76141 to enable community college districts to charge all non-resident students a capital outlay fee, not only those students who were both citizens and residents of a foreign country.  
	 
In summary, the rate for all non-resident students will be $141 base rate plus $15 capital outlay rate for a total of $156 per quarter unit, representing a $4 increase over the 2015/16 rate.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Joni Hayes, Director, Budget Operations, x6261
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board approve the base rate of $141/quarter unit and the capital outlay rate of $15/quarter unit for a total of $156/unit for all non-resident students for the 2016/17 fiscal year.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill and De Anza College have requested to purchase microscopes for instruction on their respective campuses. Because the estimated cost of the microscopes may exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $86,000, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to use existing contracts awarded by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking.”  The competitively bid University of California Office of the President (UCOP) contract with Olympus Inc. is available and it includes the items that are required by the colleges. District staff have reviewed and approve of using the University of California contract. 
	 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than the prices offered on the University of California contract for the same goods and services. The UCOP contract awarded to Olympus America Inc. establishes discounts for various microscopes, confocal systems, and miscellaneous equipment and includes delivery, warranty, set up, and installation.  
	 
Submitted by:
 Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, x6166
Additional contact names:
Nanette Solvason, Anita Muthyala-Kandula, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis: 
	 
The California Education Code and Administrative Code require K-14 school buildings to conform to the requirements of the Field Act, provisions that generally require a higher level of structural safety for buildings that house students and their teachers for instructional school functions. 
	 
The Codes exempt many non-school buildings, such as the New District Offices, from the Field Act.  Administrative Code 4-310 succinctly summarizes those instances where the Field Act need not apply.   District-wide administrative buildings are exempt from the Field Act 1) when on sites separate from school sites and 2) which are not to be used or entered by pupils or teachers for credit/non-credit instructional purposes.
	 
The New District Offices site, while nominally located at Foothill College, occupies a corner of the District’s Los Altos Hills property that is distinctly separated from the campus by vehicle access, appearance and natural features.  In addition, an adjustment of property lot lines will define the site as being separate from the College, so the project will be located on a separate site to satisfy the first criterion for exemption. 
	 
The New District Offices need not be entered by students or instructors, as such, for school purposes so the project meets the second criterion for exemption; classroom buildings and College administrative buildings serve students for school functions rather than the New District Offices.
	 
While it is not mandatory to obtain Division of the State Architect (DSA) concurrence that the project is exempt from the Field Act,  the District has received documented agreement from DSA that the project is Field Act exempt.  
	 
The Administrative Code does require the school board to pass a resolution, to be submitted to DSA, containing the specific provisions included in the attached Resolution.  
	 
The New District Offices will be designed to current California building codes, which also cover all California State University and University of California buildings, including classroom buildings. The project will be reviewed by DSA for access compliance only, a requirement of the Government Code.  
	 
Exempting the project design from the Field Act will result in cost and time savings to the project.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor x6201; Art Heinrich, Director x6295
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On June 6, 2006, voters in the Foothill-De Anza Community College District approved a $490.8 million general obligation bond measure (Measure C) under the rules established by Proposition 39.  Proposition 39 accountability requirements include annual performance and financial audits on use of bond proceeds.
	 
The Measure C performance and financial audits were prepared by the independent certified public accounting firm of Vavrinek, Trine, Day & Company, LLP, located in Pleasanton, California.  The performance audit was prepared in accordance with Education Code Section 15286, which requires that the audit be conducted in accordance with Governmental Auditing Standards, issued by the Comptroller General of the United States.
	 
The financial audit was conducted in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States and the standards applicable to financial audits contained in Governmental Auditing Standards, issued by the Comptroller General of the United States.
	 
The District Audit and Finance Committee will review the Measure C Performance and Financial Audit reports at their regularly scheduled meeting on March 10, 2016.  Copies of the reports are available for public viewing in the Chancellor's Office.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The project consists of removal and replacement of the roof and subsurface drainage system to Foothill College Building 2700.  This work is necessary because the subsurface drainage system in the pool area is no longer functioning, causing leaks in the lower levels of the buildings.  The system was installed as part of the original campus construction and the aging system has been modified several times over the years, so it no longer works as intended.  The project provides new underground drain lines and improved pathways for roof drain water to prevent water intrusion into the building.
	 
Salas O’Brien prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
Bid #1742-118 was legally advertised in the San Jose Post Record on October 28 and November 4, 2015 and  the bid documents were broadcasted through FHDA’s Purchasing web page.  A mandatory bid walk was held on November 10, 2015, and a total of four (4) contractors attended the walk. Bids were publicly opened and read on December 2, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office.  Two (2) contractors submitted a bid and the bid results are summarized below:
	 
General Contractors
Base Bid Proposal Amount Includes  $10,000 Allowance 1
Rodan Builders, Inc.
$134,000
Guerra Construction Group.
$137,474
	 
	 
Rodan Builders, Inc. and its listed subcontractor have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  
	 
Rodan Builders, Inc. has successfully completed the following projects: #100O- Tennis Courts Renovation at Foothill, #120, Smithwick Theater Hardware Improvements and #261 Shaft Safety & Guardrail at De Anza College. 
	 
The total bid proposal price of $134,000 submitted by Rodan Builders, Inc. is over the engineer estimate of $80,000, however it is within the overall project budget of $160,000. The current bid climate, potential threats of weather during this project, and the need to work evenings and weekends to complete the project are all factors why the bid was higher than engineers estimate. Therefore, the Measure C Bond team recommends award of a contract for the base bid proposal amount to Rodan Builders, Inc.  This project is funded by Measure C.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Steve Kitchen, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
 
 Foothill College has requested to purchase ultrasound equipment for instruction to replace aging equipment that is obsolete. Because the estimated cost of the ultrasound equipment will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $87,800, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts awarded by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking”.  The competitively bid University of California Office of the President (UCOP) contract with Olympus Inc. is available and it includes the items that are required by the college. 
	 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than the prices offered on the University of California contract for the same goods and services. The UCOP contract awarded to General Electric Healthcare establishes discounts for various ultrasound equipment and is inclusive of delivery and installation.  
	 
The ultrasound equipment will be purchased using Foothill College Measure C fund.  
 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Bernata Slater, Nanette Solvason, Kathleen Austin, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
